title: 106_s289
content: The "Faith-Based Drug Treatment Enhancement Act" amends the Public Health Service Act to allow services for substance abuse prevention and treatment to be provided through religious organizations. This Act may be cited as the "Faith-Based Drug Treatment Enhancement Act". This part of the Act applies to programs providing Federal financial assistance for substance abuse prevention or treatment. It excludes awards for other purposes. Definitions include 'designated award recipient' and 'designated direct award'. The Act applies to programs offering Federal financial assistance for substance abuse prevention or treatment, excluding awards for other purposes. Definitions include 'designated direct award', 'designated subaward', 'designated program', 'financial assistance', 'program beneficiary', 'program participant', and 'program services'. The term 'program services' refers to substance abuse treatment or preventive services provided under a designated program. 'Religious organization' is defined as a nonprofit religious organization. 'Voucherized assistance' involves selecting and reimbursing program services through a system where beneficiaries are given authorization to pay for services and choose the organization providing them. The beneficiary is reimbursed by the award recipient for program services provided, or they can choose a service provider to allocate program funds for services. SEC. 582 states that religious organizations can participate in programs. Religious organizations have the authority to be designated award recipients, make subawards to other entities, provide program services through voucherized assistance, and be service providers under designated programs. The term "program participant" includes entities that have received direct awards or subawards, even if they only provide services through voucherized assistance. Religious organizations can participate in designated programs by providing program services with voucherized assistance. The section allows them to participate without compromising their religious character or the religious freedom of beneficiaries. Congress finds that social-welfare programs should not discriminate against faith-based providers or require them to abandon their religious identity to participate in Federal programs. Religious organizations are eligible to participate on equal terms with other nonprofit private providers. Religious organizations can participate in programs without discrimination based on their religious character. They are allowed to maintain independence from government control over their religious beliefs and practices. Additionally, they are not required to change their internal governance or remove religious symbols. Religious organizations participating in programs are not required to alter their internal governance or remove religious symbols. Employees providing program services may need to adhere to the organization's religious beliefs and practices, as well as any rules regarding drug or alcohol use. If an individual objects to a program participant being a religious organization, alternative arrangements must be made for the individual to receive program services through a different entity or provider. Alternative arrangements must be made for individuals who object to a religious organization being a program participant, ensuring they receive program services of equal value through a different provider. The religious organization must not discriminate based on religion when providing program services, except when a beneficiary chooses to receive services from that organization. The religious organization chosen by a beneficiary to receive program services must allow active participation in religious activities and follow religious-based rules of behavior. The organization must adhere to fiscal accountability regulations for Federal financial assistance, with separate audits for Federal funds if kept in a distinct account. SEC. 583 prohibits the use of funds for sectarian worship or instruction, except when the beneficiary can choose where the assistance is redeemed. SEC. 584 addresses the administration of the program and treatment of funds. SEC. 584 discusses the administration of designated program funds, clarifying that financial assistance is aid to the beneficiary, not the organization providing services. It also prohibits state discrimination in the use of funds at religious facilities. The Congress finds that formal educational qualifications for counselors in drug treatment programs may hinder program effectiveness and service provision. States must recognize the value of religious education and training for personnel in program services. The Congress acknowledges the importance of religious education and training for personnel in drug treatment programs. States can establish educational qualifications for program personnel, with exceptions for religious organizations with a successful track record in drug treatment.
